4. Statistics
4.1 Intro
We estimate probability models parameters θ\thetaθ﻿ from data D\mathcal{D}D﻿. Most methods are optimizations of the form:
θ^=arg min⁡θL(θ)\begin{equation} \hat{\theta}=\argmin_{\theta} \mathcal{L}(\theta) \end{equation}θ^=θargmin​L(θ)​​
4.2 Maximum likelihood estimation (MLE)
4.2.1 Definition
Pick the parameter estimation assigning the highest probability to the training data, defined as:
θ^mle≜arg max⁡θp(D∣θ)\begin{equation} \hat{\theta}_{mle} \triangleq \argmax_{\theta}p(\mathcal{D}|\theta) \end{equation}θ^mle​≜θargmax​p(D∣θ)​​
Wit the i.i.d. assumptions this becomes:
p(D∣θ)=∏n=1Np(yn∣xn,θ)\begin{equation} p(\mathcal{D}|\theta)=\prod^N_{n=1}p(\bold{y}_n|\bold{x}_n,\theta) \end{equation}p(D∣θ)=n=1∏N​p(yn​∣xn​,θ)​​
And the Negative Log Likelihood (since most optimization algorithms are designed to minimize cost functions)
NLL(θ)≜−∑n=1Nlog⁡p(yn∣xn,θ)\begin{equation} NLL(\theta)\triangleq -\sum^N_{n=1}\log p(\bold{y}_n|\bold{x}_n,\theta) \end{equation}NLL(θ)≜−n=1∑N​logp(yn​∣xn​,θ)​​
With
θ^mle=arg min⁡θNLL(θ)\hat{\theta}_{mle}= \argmin_{\theta} NLL(\theta)θ^mle​=θargmin​NLL(θ)
4.2.2 Justification for MLE
MLE can be viewed as a point estimation to the Bayesian posterior p(θ∣D)p(\theta|\mathcal{D})p(θ∣D)﻿
θ^map=arg max⁡θlog⁡p(θ∣D)=arg max⁡log⁡p(D∣θ)+log⁡p(θ)\hat{\theta}_{map}= \argmax_{\theta} \log p(\theta|\mathcal{D})=\argmax \log p(\mathcal{D}|\theta)+\log p(\theta)θ^map​=θargmax​logp(θ∣D)=argmaxlogp(D∣θ)+logp(θ)
So θ^map=θ^mle\hat{\theta}_{map}=\hat{\theta}_{mle}θ^map​=θ^mle​﻿ if the prior is uniform.
Another way to see the MLE is that the resulting predictive distribution p(y∣θ^mle)p(y|\hat{\theta}_{mle})p(y∣θ^mle​)﻿ is as close as possible to the empirical distribution of the data.
If we defined the empirical distribution by
pD(y)≜1N∑n=1Nδ(y−yn)\begin{equation} p_{\mathcal{D}}(\bold{y}) \triangleq \frac{1}{N} \sum_{n=1}^N\delta(y-y_n) \end{equation}pD​(y)≜N1​n=1∑N​δ(y−yn​)​​
Minimizing the KL divergence between the empirical p=pDp=p_{\mathcal{D}}p=pD​﻿ and an estimated distribution q=p(yn∣θ)q=p(y_n|\theta)q=p(yn​∣θ)﻿ is equivalent to minimizing the NLL and therefore computing the MLE.
DKL(p∣∣q)≜∑yp(y)log⁡p(y)q(y)=−H(pD)−1N∑n=1Nlog⁡p(yn∣θ)=const+NLL(θ)\begin{align} D_{\mathbb{KL}}(p||q) &\triangleq \sum_y p(y) \log \frac{p(y)}{q(y)} \\ &= -\mathbb{H}(p_{\mathcal{D}}) -\frac{1}{N} \sum_{n=1}^N \log p(y_n|\theta) \\ &= \mathrm{const} +\mathrm{NLL}(\theta) \end{align} DKL​(p∣∣q)​≜y∑​p(y)logq(y)p(y)​=−H(pD​)−N1​n=1∑N​logp(yn​∣θ)=const+NLL(θ)​​
The same logic applies for supervised settings, with:
pD(x,y)=pD(y∣x)pD(x)=1N∑n=1Nδ(x−xn)δ(y−yn)p_{D}(x,y)=p_{\mathcal{D}}(y|x) p_{\mathcal{D}}(x)=\frac{1}{N} \sum_{n=1}^N \delta(x-x_n)\delta(y-y_n)pD​(x,y)=pD​(y∣x)pD​(x)=N1​n=1∑N​δ(x−xn​)δ(y−yn​)
4.2.3 MLE for the Bernoulli distribution
Let θ=p(Y=1)\theta =p(Y=1)θ=p(Y=1)﻿ be the probability of heads in a coin toss.
NLL(θ)=−log⁡∏n=1Np(yn∣θ)=−log⁡∏n=1NθI(yn=1)(1−θ)I(yn=0)=−[N1log⁡θ+N0log⁡(1−θ)]\begin{align} \mathrm{NLL}(\theta)&=-\log \prod^N_{n=1}p(y_n|\theta) \\ &=-\log \prod^N_{n=1}\theta^{\mathbb{I}(y_n=1)}(1-\theta)^{\mathbb{I}(y_n=0)} \\ &= -[N_1 \log\theta+N_0 \log(1-\theta)] \end{align}NLL(θ)​=−logn=1∏N​p(yn​∣θ)=−logn=1∏N​θI(yn​=1)(1−θ)I(yn​=0)=−[N1​logθ+N0​log(1−θ)]​​
The MLE can be found by:
ddθNLL(θ)=−N1θ+N01−θ⇒θ^mle=N1N\frac{d}{d\theta} \mathrm{NLL}(\theta)=- \frac{N_1}{\theta}+\frac{N_0}{1-\theta} \Rightarrow \hat{\theta}_{mle}=\frac{N_1}{N}dθd​NLL(θ)=−θN1​​+1−θN0​​⇒θ^mle​=NN1​​
4.2.4 MLE for the categorical distribution
Let Yn∼Cat(θ)Y_n \sim \mathrm{Cat}(\theta)Yn​∼Cat(θ)﻿.
NLL(θ)=−∑kNklog⁡θk\mathrm{NLL}(\theta)=-\sum_k N_k \log \theta_kNLL(θ)=−k∑​Nk​logθk​
To compute the MLE, we have to minimize the NLL subject the constraint ∑k=1Kθk=1\sum^K_{k=1}\theta_k=1∑k=1K​θk​=1﻿ using the following Lagrangian:
L(θ,λ)≜−∑kNklog⁡θk−λ(1−∑kθk)\mathcal{L}(\theta,\lambda) \triangleq -\sum_kN_k \log \theta_k-\lambda \Big(1-\sum_k \theta_k\Big)L(θ,λ)≜−k∑​Nk​logθk​−λ(1−k∑​θk​)
We get the MLE by taking the derivative of L\mathcal{L}L﻿ for λ\lambdaλ﻿ and θk\theta_kθk​﻿
θ^k=Nkλ=NkN\hat{\theta}_k=\frac{N_k}{\lambda}=\frac{N_k}{N}θ^k​=λNk​​=NNk​​
4.2.5 MLE for the univariate Gaussian
Suppose Y∼N(μ,σ2)Y \sim N(\mu,\sigma^2)Y∼N(μ,σ2)﻿. We estimate here again the parameters using the MLE:
NLL(μ,σ2)=−∑n=1Nlog⁡[(12πσ2)12exp⁡(−(yn−μ)22σ2)]=12σ2∑n=1N(yn−μ)2+N2log⁡(2πσ2)\begin{align} \mathrm{NLL}(\mu,\sigma^2) &=-\sum_{n=1}^N \log \Big[\big(\frac{1}{2\pi\sigma^2}\big)^{\frac{1}{2}} \exp\big(-\frac{(y_n-\mu)^2}{2\sigma^2}\big)\Big] \\ &= \frac{1}{2\sigma^2}\sum_{n=1}^N(y_n-\mu)^2 + \frac{N}{2}\log (2\pi\sigma^2) \end{align}NLL(μ,σ2)​=−n=1∑N​log[(2πσ21​)21​exp(−2σ2(yn​−μ)2​)]=2σ21​n=1∑N​(yn​−μ)2+2N​log(2πσ2)​​
We find the stationary point by ∂∂μNLL(μ,σ2)=0\frac{\partial}{\partial \mu}\mathrm{NLL}(\mu,\sigma^2)=0∂μ∂​NLL(μ,σ2)=0﻿ and ∂∂σ2NLL(μ,σ2)=0\frac{\partial}{\partial \sigma^2}\mathrm{NLL}(\mu,\sigma^2)=0∂σ2∂​NLL(μ,σ2)=0﻿
μ^mle=1N∑n=1Nyn=yˉσ^mle2=1N∑n=1N(yn−μ^mle)2=s2−yˉ2s2≜1N∑n=1Nyn2\begin{align} \hat{\mu}_{mle} &=\frac{1}{N}\sum_{n=1}^N y_n=\bar{y} \\ \hat{\sigma}^2_{mle} &= \frac{1}{N}\sum^N_{n=1}(y_n-\hat{\mu}_{mle})^2=s^2- \bar{y}^2 \\ s^2& \triangleq \frac{1}{N}\sum^N_{n=1}y_n^2 \end{align} μ^​mle​σ^mle2​s2​=N1​n=1∑N​yn​=yˉ​=N1​n=1∑N​(yn​−μ^​mle​)2=s2−yˉ​2≜N1​n=1∑N​yn2​​​
yˉ\bar{y}yˉ​﻿ and s2s^2s2﻿ are the sufficient statistics of the data, since they are sufficient to compute the MLE.
The unbiased estimator for variance (not the MLE) is:
σ^unb2=1N−1∑n=1N(yn−μ^mle)2\hat{\sigma}^2_{unb}=\frac{1}{N-1} \sum^N_{n=1}(y_n-\hat{\mu}_{mle})^2σ^unb2​=N−11​n=1∑N​(yn​−μ^​mle​)2
4.2.6 MLE for MVN
LL(μ,Σ)=log⁡p(D∣μ,Σ)=−12∑n=1N(yn−μ)⊤Λ(yn−μ)+N2log⁡∣Λ∣\mathrm{LL}(\mu,\Sigma)=\log p(\mathcal{D}|\mu,\Sigma)=-\frac{1}{2}\sum_{n=1}^N(y_n-\mu)^\top\Lambda(y_n-\mu)+\frac{N}{2} \log|\Lambda|LL(μ,Σ)=logp(D∣μ,Σ)=−21​n=1∑N​(yn​−μ)⊤Λ(yn​−μ)+2N​log∣Λ∣
with Λ=Σ−1\Lambda=\Sigma^{-1}Λ=Σ−1﻿ the precision matrix.
Using zn=yn−μz_n=y_n-\muzn​=yn​−μ﻿:
∂∂μ(yn−μ)⊤Σ−1(yn−μ)=∂∂znzn⊤Σ−1zn∂zn∂μ=−(Σ−1+Σ−T)zn\frac{\partial}{\partial \mu}(y_n-\mu)^\top \Sigma^{-1}(y_n-\mu)=\frac{\partial}{\partial z_n}z_n^\top\Sigma^{-1}z_n\frac{\partial z_n}{\partial \mu}=-(\Sigma^{-1}+\Sigma^{-T})z_n∂μ∂​(yn​−μ)⊤Σ−1(yn​−μ)=∂zn​∂​zn⊤​Σ−1zn​∂μ∂zn​​=−(Σ−1+Σ−T)zn​
Hence
∂∂μLL(μ,Σ)=−12∑−2Σ−1(yn−μ)=0⇒μ^=yˉ\frac{\partial}{\partial \mu}\mathrm{LL}(\mu,\Sigma)=-\frac{1}{2}\sum -2\Sigma^{-1}(y_n-\mu)=0 \\\Rightarrow \hat{\mu}=\bar{y}∂μ∂​LL(μ,Σ)=−21​∑−2Σ−1(yn​−μ)=0⇒μ^​=yˉ​
So the MLE of μ\muμ﻿ is just the empirical mean.
Using the trace trick:
LL(μ^,Λ)=−12∑ntr[(yn−μ)(yn−μ)⊤Λ]+N2log⁡∣Λ∣=−12tr[SyˉΛ]+N2log⁡∣Λ∣\begin{align} \mathrm{LL}(\hat{\mu},\Lambda)&=-\frac{1}{2} \sum_ntr[(y_n-\mu)(y_n-\mu)^\top \Lambda]+\frac{N}{2}\log |\Lambda| \\ &= -\frac{1}{2} tr[S_{\bar{y}} \Lambda]+\frac{N}{2}\log |\Lambda| \end{align}LL(μ^​,Λ)​=−21​n∑​tr[(yn​−μ)(yn​−μ)⊤Λ]+2N​log∣Λ∣=−21​tr[Syˉ​​Λ]+2N​log∣Λ∣​​
With Syˉ=∑n(yn−yˉ)(yn−yˉ)⊤S_{\bar{y}}=\sum_n(y_n-\bar{y})(y_n-\bar{y})^\topSyˉ​​=∑n​(yn​−yˉ​)(yn​−yˉ​)⊤﻿ the scatter matrix centered on yˉ\bar{y}yˉ​﻿
Resolving the derivative for Λ\LambdaΛ﻿ gives Λ^−1=Σ=1NSyˉ\hat{\Lambda}^{-1}=\Sigma=\frac{1}{N} S_{\bar{y}}Λ^−1=Σ=N1​Syˉ​​﻿
4.2.7 MLE for linear regression
Let suppose the model corresponds to p(y∣x,θ)=N(y∣w⊤x,σ2)p(y|x,\theta)=\mathcal{N}(y|w^\top x,\sigma^2)p(y∣x,θ)=N(y∣w⊤x,σ2)﻿. If we fix σ2\sigma^2σ2﻿ to focus on www﻿:
LL(w)=−∑n=1Nlog⁡[(12πσ2)1/2exp⁡(−12σ2(yn−w⊤xn)2)]\mathrm{LL}(w)=-\sum_{n=1}^N \log \Bigg[ \Big(\frac{1}{2\pi\sigma^2}\Big)^{1/2} \exp\Big(-\frac{1}{2\sigma^2}(y_n-w^\top x_n)^2\Big) \Bigg]LL(w)=−n=1∑N​log[(2πσ21​)1/2exp(−2σ21​(yn​−w⊤xn​)2)]
Dropping the irrelevant additive constants:
RSS(w)≜∑n=1N(yn−w⊤xn)2=∑n=1Nrn2\mathrm{RSS}(w) \triangleq \sum_{n=1}^N (y_n-w^\top x_n)^2=\sum^N_{n=1}r_n^2RSS(w)≜n=1∑N​(yn​−w⊤xn​)2=n=1∑N​rn2​
Note that MSE=1NRSS\mathrm{MSE}=\frac{1}{N}\mathrm{RSS}MSE=N1​RSS﻿ and RMSE=MSE\mathrm{RMSE}=\sqrt{MSE}RMSE=MSE​﻿
Writing the RSS\mathrm{RSS}RSS﻿ in matrix notation:
RSS(w)=∣∣Xw⊤−y∣∣22\mathrm{RSS}(w)=||\bold{X}w^\top-\bold{y}||^2_2RSS(w)=∣∣Xw⊤−y∣∣22​
And the equation of OLS is:
w^mle≜arg min⁡wRSS(w)=(X⊤X)−1X⊤y\hat{w}_{mle} \triangleq \argmin_w \mathrm{RSS}(w) = \bold{(X^\top X)^{-1}X^\top y}w^mle​≜wargmin​RSS(w)=(X⊤X)−1X⊤y
4.3 Empirical risk minimization (ERM)
We can generalize the MLE by replacing the loss loss term with any other loss to get:
L(θ)=1N∑n=1Nl(yn,xn,θ)\mathcal{L}(\theta)=\frac{1}{N}\sum_{n=1}^N\mathcal{l}(y_n,x_n,\theta)L(θ)=N1​n=1∑N​l(yn​,xn​,θ)
4.3.1 Misclassification rate
Let y~∈{−1,+1}\tilde{y} \in \{-1,+1\}y~​∈{−1,+1}﻿ our true label and y^∈{−1,+1}=f(x,θ)\hat{y}\in \{-1,+1\}=f(x,\theta)y^​∈{−1,+1}=f(x,θ)﻿ our prediction
We can define the loss as the misclassification rate l01(y~,y^)=I(y~≠y^)=I(y~y^<0)l_{01}(\tilde{y},\hat{y})=\mathbb{I}(\tilde{y} \neq \hat{y})=\mathbb{I}(\tilde{y} \hat{y}<0)l01​(y~​,y^​)=I(y~​=y^​)=I(y~​y^​<0)﻿
4.3.2 Surrogate loss
Unfortunately, the 0-1 loss is non smooth, making it NP-hard to optimize. Here we use a surrogate loss function, a maximally tight convex upper bound, easy to minimize.
For exemple, let
p(y~∣x,θ)=σ(y~η)=11+e−y~ηp(\tilde{y}|x,\theta) = \sigma(\tilde{y}\eta )=\frac{1}{1+e^{-\tilde{y}\eta}}p(y~​∣x,θ)=σ(y~​η)=1+e−y~​η1​
where η=f(x,θ)\eta=f(x,\theta)η=f(x,θ)﻿ is the logs odds
The log loss is
l(y~,η)=log⁡(1+e−y~η)l(\tilde{y},\eta)=\log(1+e^{-\tilde{y}\eta})l(y~​,η)=log(1+e−y~​η)
This is a smooth upper bound to the 0-1 loss where y~η\tilde{y}\etay~​η﻿ is the margin (it defines a “margin of safety” away from the threshold at 0)
4.4 Other estimation methods
4.4.1 The methods of moment (MOM)
MOM is a simpler approach than computing MLE. Solve KKK﻿ number of equations (KKK﻿ is the number of parameters).
The theoretical moments are given by μk=E[Yk]\mu_k=\mathbb{E}[Y^k]μk​=E[Yk]﻿
The empirical moments are given by μ^k=1N∑nynk\hat{\mu}_k=\frac{1}{N}\sum_ny_n^kμ^​k​=N1​∑n​ynk​﻿
We solve μk=μ^k\mu_k=\hat{\mu}_kμk​=μ^​k​﻿ for every k.
Example with the univariate Gaussian:
μ1=μ=yˉ\mu_1=\mu=\bar{y}μ1​=μ=yˉ​﻿
μ2=σ2+μ2=s2\mu_2=\sigma^2+\mu^2=s^2μ2​=σ2+μ2=s2﻿ (since σ2=s2−μ2\sigma^2=s^2-\mu^2σ2=s2−μ2﻿)
so:
μ^=yˉ\hat{\mu}=\bar{y}μ^​=yˉ​﻿
σ^2=s2−yˉ2\hat{\sigma}^2=s^2-\bar{y}^2σ^2=s2−yˉ​2﻿
So in this case, this is similar to MLE.
Example with the uniform distribution:
p(y∣θ)=1θ2−θ1I(θ1≤y≤θ2)p(y|\theta)=\frac{1}{\theta_2-\theta_1} \mathbb{I}(\theta_1\leq y\leq\theta_2)p(y∣θ)=θ2​−θ1​1​I(θ1​≤y≤θ2​)
μ1=E[Y]=θ1+θ22\mu_1=\mathbb{E}[Y]=\frac{\theta_1+\theta_2}{2}μ1​=E[Y]=2θ1​+θ2​​﻿
μ2=E[Y2]=θ12+θ2θ1+θ123\mu_2=\mathbb{E}[Y^2]=\frac{\theta_1^2+\theta_2\theta_1+\theta_1^2}{3}μ2​=E[Y2]=3θ12​+θ2​θ1​+θ12​​﻿
Inverting these equations to get θ1\theta_1θ1​﻿ and θ2\theta_2θ2​﻿, we see that these estimators sometimes give incorrect results.
To compute the MLE, we sort the data values. The likelihood is:
p(D∣θ1,θ1)=(1θ2−θ1)NI(θ1≤y1)I(yN≤θ2)p(\mathcal{D}|\theta_1, \theta_1)=(\frac{1}{\theta_2-\theta_1})^N \mathbb{I}(\theta_1\leq y_1)\mathbb{I}(y_N\leq\theta_2)p(D∣θ1​,θ1​)=(θ2​−θ1​1​)NI(θ1​≤y1​)I(yN​≤θ2​)
Then, if we set θ=θ2−θ1\theta=\theta_2-\theta_1θ=θ2​−θ1​﻿
ddθNLL(θ)=Nθ2−θ1\frac{d}{d\theta} \mathrm{NLL}(\theta)=\frac{N}{\theta_2-\theta_1}dθd​NLL(θ)=θ2​−θ1​N​
This is minimized by θ^1=y1\hat{\theta}_1=y_1θ^1​=y1​﻿ and θ^2=yN\hat{\theta}_2=y_Nθ^2​=yN​﻿, as one would expect.
4.4.2 Online (recursive) estimation
When data arrives sequentially we perform online learning.
Let θ^t−1\hat{\theta}_{t-1}θ^t−1​﻿ our estimate (e.g. MLE) given D1:t−1\mathcal{D}_{1:t-1}D1:t−1​﻿. To ensure our algorithms takes a constant time per update, our solution is in the form:
θ^t=f(θ^t−1,ft)\hat{\theta}_t=f(\hat{\theta}_{t-1},f_t)θ^t​=f(θ^t−1​,ft​)
Example for the mean of Gaussian:
μ^t=∑n=1tyn=1t((t−1)μ^t−1+yt)=μ^t−1+1t(yt−μ^t−1)\hat{\mu}_t=\sum_{n=1}^t y_n=\frac{1}{t}\Big((t-1)\hat{\mu}_{t-1}+y_t\Big)=\hat{\mu}_{t-1}+\frac{1}{t}(y_t-\hat{\mu}_{t-1})μ^​t​=n=1∑t​yn​=t1​((t−1)μ^​t−1​+yt​)=μ^​t−1​+t1​(yt​−μ^​t−1​)
This is a moving average, the size of the correction diminish over time. However if the distribution is changing, we might want to give more weight to recent data points.
This is solved by exponentially-weighted moving average (EWMA)
μ^t=βμ^t—1+(1−β)yt\hat{\mu}_t=\beta \hat{\mu}_{t—1}+(1-\beta)y_tμ^​t​=βμ^​t—1​+(1−β)yt​
with 0<β<10<\beta<10<β<1﻿
The contribution of a data point in k steps is βk(1−β)\beta^k(1-\beta)βk(1−β)﻿.
Since the initial estimate starts from μ^0=0\hat{\mu}_0=0μ^​0​=0﻿ there is an initial bias, corrected by scaling as
μ~t=μ^t1−βt\tilde{\mu}_t=\frac{\hat{\mu}_t}{1-\beta^t}μ~​t​=1−βtμ^​t​​
4.5 Regularization
The main issue with MLE and ERM is that they pick parameters minimizing the loss on the training set, which can result in overfitting.
With enough parameters, a model can match any empirical distribution. However, in most cases the empirical distribution is not the same as the true distribution. Regularization add a penalty term to the NLL.
L(θ,λ)=1N∑i=1Nl(yn,θ,xn)+λC(θ)=−1N∑i=1Nlog⁡p(yn∣xn,θ)−λlog⁡p(θ)\begin{align} \mathcal{L}(\theta,\lambda)&=\frac{1}{N}\sum^N_{i=1}l(y_n,\theta,x_n)+\lambda C(\theta) \\ &=-\frac{1}{N}\sum^N_{i=1} \log p(y_n|x_n,\theta) -\lambda \log p(\theta) \end{align} L(θ,λ)​=N1​i=1∑N​l(yn​,θ,xn​)+λC(θ)=−N1​i=1∑N​logp(yn​∣xn​,θ)−λlogp(θ)​​
by taking the log loss and the log prior for penalty term.
This is equivalent to minimizing the MAP:
θ^map=arg max⁡θlog⁡p(θ∣D)=arg max⁡θ[log⁡p(D∣θ)+log⁡p(θ)−const]\hat{\theta}_{map}=\argmax_{\theta} \log p(\theta|\mathcal{D})=\argmax_{\theta} [\log p(\mathcal{D}|\theta)+\log p(\theta) -\mathrm{const}]θ^map​=θargmax​logp(θ∣D)=θargmax​[logp(D∣θ)+logp(θ)−const]
4.5.1 MAP for Bernoulli distribution
If we observe just one head, θmle=1\theta_{mle}=1θmle​=1﻿. We add a penalty to θ\thetaθ﻿ to discourage extreme values.
With p(θ)∼Beta(a,b)p(\theta)\sim Beta(a,b)p(θ)∼Beta(a,b)﻿, and a,b>1a,b>1a,b>1﻿, we encourage values of θ\thetaθ﻿ near to the mean a/(a+b){a}/(a+b)a/(a+b)﻿
LL(θ)=log⁡p(D∣θ)+log⁡p(θ)=N0log⁡θ+N1log⁡(1−θ)+(a−1)log⁡θ+(b−1)log⁡(1−θ)\begin{align} \mathrm{LL}(\theta)&=\log p(\mathcal{D}|\theta)+\log p(\theta) \\ &= N_0 \log\theta+ N_1 \log(1 - \theta) + (a-1)\log \theta + (b-1)\log (1-\theta) \end{align}LL(θ)​=logp(D∣θ)+logp(θ)=N0​logθ+N1​log(1−θ)+(a−1)logθ+(b−1)log(1−θ)​​
With the same method as the MLE, we find:
θ^map=N1+a−1N+a+b−2=N1+1N+2\hat{\theta}_{map}=\frac{N_1+a-1}{N+a+b-2}=\frac{N_1+1}{N+2}θ^map​=N+a+b−2N1​+a−1​=N+2N1​+1​
By setting a=2,b=2a=2, b=2a=2,b=2﻿, we resolve the zero-count problem.
Regularization combines empirical data and prior knowledge.
4.5.2 MAP for MVN
We showed that the MLE for covariance of a MVN is Σ^=1NSyˉ\hat{\Sigma}=\frac{1}{N}S_{\bar{y}}Σ^=N1​Syˉ​​﻿. In high dimensions, the scatter matrix can easily become singular. One solution is to perform MAP estimation.
A convenient prior to use for Σ\SigmaΣ﻿ is the Wishart distribution (generalization of the Gamma distribution). The resulting MAP is:
Σ^map=S˘+SyˉN˘+N=N˘N˘+NS˘N˘+NN˘+NSyˉN=λΣ0+(1−λ)Σ^mle\hat{\Sigma}_{map}=\frac{\breve{S}+S_{\bar{y}}}{\breve{N}+N}=\frac{\breve{N}}{\breve{N}+N}\frac{\breve{S}}{\breve{N}}+\frac{N}{\breve{N}+N}\frac{S_{\bar{y}}}{N}=\lambda \Sigma_0+(1-\lambda)\hat{\Sigma}_{mle}Σ^map​=N˘+NS˘+Syˉ​​​=N˘+NN˘​N˘S˘​+N˘+NN​NSyˉ​​​=λΣ0​+(1−λ)Σ^mle​
where λ\lambdaλ﻿ controls the amount of regularization.
If we set S˘=Ndiag(Σ^mle)\breve{S}=N \mathrm{diag}(\hat{\Sigma}_{mle})S˘=Ndiag(Σ^mle​)﻿:
Σ^map(i,j)={Σ^mleif i=j(1−λ)Σ^mleo.w.\hat{\Sigma}_{map}(i,j)=\begin{cases} \hat{\Sigma}_{mle}&\mathrm{if}\,i=j \\ (1-\lambda)\hat{\Sigma}_{mle} & o.w. \end{cases}Σ^map​(i,j)={Σ^mle​(1−λ)Σ^mle​​ifi=jo.w.​
Off-diagonal elements are shrunk toward 0. λ\lambdaλ﻿ can be chosen via cross-validation of via close form (implemented in scikit-learn LedoitWolf).
The benefits of the MAP is to better behaved than MLE, with eigenvalues of the estimate closer to that of the true covariance matrix (the eigenvectors however are unaffected).
4.5.3 Weight decay
We saw that reducing the degree of the polynomial help the regression task. A more general solution is to add regularization to the regression coefficients.
w^map=arg min⁡wNLL(w)+λ∣∣w∣∣22\hat{w}_{map}=\argmin_w \mathrm{NLL}(w)+\lambda ||w||_2^2w^map​=wargmin​NLL(w)+λ∣∣w∣∣22​
where a higher λ\lambdaλ﻿ means more pressure toward low coefficients and thus less flexibility for the model. This is ridge regression.
4.5.4 Picking λ\lambdaλ﻿ by cross validation
We split the training data into K folds and iteratively fit on all fold except one, used for validation.
We have
Rλ(θ,D)=1∣D∣∑(x,y)∈Dℓ(y,f(x,θ))+λC(θ)R_\lambda(\theta,\mathcal{D})=\frac{1}{|D|}\sum_{(x,y) \in \mathcal{D}} \ell(y,f(x,\theta))+\lambda C(\theta)Rλ​(θ,D)=∣D∣1​(x,y)∈D∑​ℓ(y,f(x,θ))+λC(θ)
So
λ^=arg min⁡λRλcv=arg min⁡λ1K∑k=1KR0(θ^λ(D−k),Dk)\hat{\lambda} =\argmin_\lambda R^{cv}_\lambda =\argmin_\lambda\frac{1}{K}\sum_{k=1}^K R_0(\hat{\theta}_{\lambda}(\mathcal{D}_{-k}),\mathcal{D}_k)λ^=λargmin​Rλcv​=λargmin​K1​k=1∑K​R0​(θ^λ​(D−k​),Dk​)
Finally
θ^=arg min⁡θRλ^(θ,D)\hat{\theta}=\argmin_{\theta}R_{\hat{\lambda}}(\theta,\mathcal{D})θ^=θargmin​Rλ^​(θ,D)
The standard error of our estimate is:
se=σ^n\mathrm{se}=\frac{\hat{\sigma}}{\sqrt{n}}se=n​σ^​
where σ^=Var[ℓ(y,f(x,θ^)]\hat{\sigma}=\mathrm{Var}[\ell(y,f(x,\hat{\theta})]σ^=Var[ℓ(y,f(x,θ^)]﻿
4.5.7 Using more data
When a model is too simplistic, it fails to improve as the data grow. A overly complex model will end up converging toward the right solution if enough data is provided.
4.6 Bayesian statistics
Inference is modeling uncertainty about parameters using a probability distribution (instead of a point estimate). In Bayesian statistics we use the posterior distribution.
p(θ∣D)=p(D∣θ)p(θ)p(D)p(\theta|\mathcal{D})=\frac{p(\mathcal{D}|\theta)p(\theta)}{p(\mathcal{D})}p(θ∣D)=p(D)p(D∣θ)p(θ)​
Once we have computed the posterior over θ\thetaθ﻿, we compute the posterior predictive distribution by marginalizing out θ\thetaθ﻿. In the supervised setting:
p(y∣x,D)=∫p(y∣x,θ)p(θ∣D)dθp(y|x,\mathcal{D})=\int p(y|x,\theta)p(\theta|\mathcal{D})d\thetap(y∣x,D)=∫p(y∣x,θ)p(θ∣D)dθ
This is Bayes model averaging (BMA), since we use an infinite amount set of models, weighted by how likely their parameters are.
4.6.1 Conjugate prior
A prior p(θ)∈Fp(\theta)\in\mathcal{F}p(θ)∈F﻿ is conjugate for a likelihood function p(D∣θ)p(\mathcal{D}|\theta)p(D∣θ)﻿ if the posterior p(θ∣D)∈Fp(\theta|\mathcal{D})\in\mathcal{F}p(θ∣D)∈F﻿. The family F\mathcal{F}F﻿ is closed under bayesian updating.
For simplicity, we consider a model without covariates.
4.6.2 Beta-binomial model
We toss a coin NNN﻿ times to estimate the head probability θ\thetaθ﻿. We want to compute p(θ∣D)p(\theta|\mathcal{D})p(θ∣D)﻿.
Under the iid hypothesis:
p(D∣θ)=θN1(1−θ)N0p(\mathcal{D}|\theta)=\theta^{N_1}(1-\theta)^{N_0}p(D∣θ)=θN1​(1−θ)N0​
Instead of observing a sequence of coin toss, we can count the number of heads using a binomial likelihood
p(D∣θ)=Bin(y∣N,θ)=(Ny)θy(1−θ)N−yp(\mathcal{D}|\theta)=\mathrm{Bin}(y|N,\theta)=\binom{N}{y}\theta^{y}(1-\theta)^{N-y}p(D∣θ)=Bin(y∣N,θ)=(yN​)θy(1−θ)N−y
Since these likelihood are proportional, we will use the same inference about θ\thetaθ﻿ for both models.
The Beta distribution is the conjugate prior to Bernoulli or Binomial likelihood.
p(θ)=Beta(θ∣a,b)=θa−1(1−θ)b−1p(\theta)=\mathrm{Beta}(\theta|a,b)=\theta^{a-1}(1-\theta)^{b-1}p(θ)=Beta(θ∣a,b)=θa−1(1−θ)b−1
We obtained the posterior
p(θ∣D)=θa−1+N1(1−θ)b−1+N0=Beta(θ∣a+N1,b+N0)=Beta(θ∣a˘,b˘)\begin{align} p(\theta|\mathcal{D})&=\theta^{a-1+N_1}(1-\theta)^{b-1+N_0} \\ &=\mathrm{Beta}(\theta|a+N_1,b+N_0) \\ &=\mathrm{Beta}(\theta|\breve{a},\breve{b}) \end{align} p(θ∣D)​=θa−1+N1​(1−θ)b−1+N0​=Beta(θ∣a+N1​,b+N0​)=Beta(θ∣a˘,b˘)​​
Here the hyper-parameters of the prior a,ba,ba,b﻿ play an similar role to the sufficient statistics N1,N0N_1,N_0N1​,N0​﻿. We call a,ba,ba,b﻿ pseudo counts and N1,N0N_1,N_0N1​,N0​﻿ observed counts.
If we set a=b=2a=b=2a=b=2﻿, it would means that we have already observed 2 heads and 2 tails before we see the actual data. This is a weak preference for the value of θ=0.5\theta=0.5θ=0.5﻿ (small update in figure (a) below).
If we set a=b=1a=b=1a=b=1﻿, the prior become p(θ)=θ0(1−θ)0=Unif(θ∣0,1)p(\theta)=\theta^{0}(1-\theta)^0=\mathrm{Unif}(\theta|0,1)p(θ)=θ0(1−θ)0=Unif(θ∣0,1)﻿. The prior is uninformative, so there is no update.
Similarly to the MAP estimate already we saw in the regularization section, we have
θ^map=a+N1−1a+b+N−2\hat{\theta}_{map}=\frac{a+N_1-1}{a+b+N-2}θ^map​=a+b+N−2a+N1​−1​
If we use a=b=2a=b=2a=b=2﻿, we find back the add-one smoothing.
If we use a=b=1a=b=1a=b=1﻿, we have θ^map=θ^mle\hat{\theta}_{map}=\hat{\theta}_{mle}θ^map​=θ^mle​﻿
The posterior mean is a more robust estimation than the posterior mode since it integrates over the whole space (instead of a single point).
If p(θ∣D)=Beta(θ∣a˘,b˘)p(\theta|\mathcal{D})=\mathrm{Beta}(\theta|\breve{a},\breve{b})p(θ∣D)=Beta(θ∣a˘,b˘)﻿, the posterior mean is:
θˉ≜E[θ∣D]=a˘N˘\bar{\theta} \triangleq \mathbb{E}[\theta|\mathcal{D}]=\frac{\breve{a}}{\breve{N}}θˉ≜E[θ∣D]=N˘a˘​
with N˘=a˘+b˘\breve{N}=\breve{a}+\breve{b}N˘=a˘+b˘﻿ the strength of the posterior.
The posterior mean is a convex combination of the prior mean, m=aNabm=\frac{a}{N_{ab}}m=Nab​a​﻿ and the MLE: θ^mle=N1N\hat{\theta}_{mle}=\frac{N_1}{N}θ^mle​=NN1​​﻿
θ^map=a+N1a+b+N1+N0=NabN+NabaNab+NN+NabN1N=λm+(1−λ)θ^mle\begin{align} \hat{\theta}_{map}&=\frac{a+N_1}{a+b+N_1+N_0}\\ &=\frac{N_{ab}}{N+N_{ab}}\frac{a}{N_{ab}}+\frac{N}{N+N_{ab}}\frac{N_1}{N} \\ &= \lambda m+(1-\lambda)\hat{\theta}_{mle} \end{align}θ^map​​=a+b+N1​+N0​a+N1​​=N+Nab​Nab​​Nab​a​+N+Nab​N​NN1​​=λm+(1−λ)θ^mle​​​
The variance of a Beta posterior is given by:
V[θ∣D]=a˘b˘(a˘+b˘)2(a˘+b˘+1)≈N1N0N3=θ(1−θ)N\mathbb{V}[\theta|\mathcal{D}]=\frac{\breve{a}\breve{b}}{(\breve{a}+\breve{b})^2(\breve{a}+\breve{b}+1)}\approx \frac{N_1N_0}{N^3}=\frac{\theta(1-\theta)}{N}V[θ∣D]=(a˘+b˘)2(a˘+b˘+1)a˘b˘​≈N3N1​N0​​=Nθ(1−θ)​
Thus, the standard error of our estimate (aka the posterior variance) is:
se(θ)=V[θ∣D]=θ(1−θ)Nse(\theta)=\sqrt{\mathbb{V}[\theta|\mathcal{D}]}=\sqrt{\frac{\theta(1-\theta)}{N}}se(θ)=V[θ∣D]​=Nθ(1−θ)​​
For the Bernoulli distribution, the posterior predictive distribution has the form:
p(y=1∣D)=∫01p(y=1∣θ)p(θ∣D)dθ=∫01θ Beta(θ∣a,b)dθ=E[θ∣D]=a˘a˘+b˘\begin{align} p(y=1|\mathcal{D})&=\int^1_0 p(y=1|\theta)p(\theta|\mathcal{D})d\theta \\ &= \int^1_0\theta\, \mathrm{Beta} (\theta|a,b)d\theta \\ &= \mathbb{E}[\theta|\mathcal{D}] \\ &= \frac{\breve{a}}{\breve{a}+\breve{b}} \end{align} p(y=1∣D)​=∫01​p(y=1∣θ)p(θ∣D)dθ=∫01​θBeta(θ∣a,b)dθ=E[θ∣D]=a˘+b˘a˘​​​
For the Binomial distribution, the posterior predictive distribution has the form of the Beta-Binomial distribution:
p(y∣D,M)=∫01Bin(y∣M,θ) Beta(θ∣a˘,b˘)dθ=(My)1B(a˘,b˘)∫01θy(1−θ)M−yθa˘−1(1−θ)b˘−1dθ=(My)B(y+a˘,M−y+b˘)B(a˘,b˘)≜Bb(y∣M,a˘,b˘)\begin{align} p(y|\mathcal{D},M)&=\int^1_0\mathrm{Bin}(y|M,\theta)\,\mathrm{Beta}(\theta|\breve{a},\breve{b})d\theta \\ &= \binom{M}{y}\frac{1}{\Beta(\breve{a},\breve{b})}\int^1_0\theta^y(1-\theta)^{M-y}\theta^{\breve{a}-1}(1-\theta)^{\breve{b}-1}d\theta \\ &=\binom{M}{y}\frac{\Beta(y+\breve{a},M-y+\breve{b})}{\Beta(\breve{a},\breve{b})} \\ &\triangleq \mathrm{Bb}(y|M,\breve{a},\breve{b}) \end{align}p(y∣D,M)​=∫01​Bin(y∣M,θ)Beta(θ∣a˘,b˘)dθ=(yM​)B(a˘,b˘)1​∫01​θy(1−θ)M−yθa˘−1(1−θ)b˘−1dθ=(yM​)B(a˘,b˘)B(y+a˘,M−y+b˘)​≜Bb(y∣M,a˘,b˘)​​
We plot in figure (a) below the posterior predictive distribution for M=10,N1=4,N0=1M=10,N_1=4,N_0=1M=10,N1​=4,N0​=1﻿, with a uniform prior Beta(θ∣1,1)\mathrm{Beta}(\theta|1,1)Beta(θ∣1,1)﻿.
(Remember that a˘=a+N1\breve{a}=a+N_1a˘=a+N1​﻿ and b˘=b+N0\breve{b}=b+N_0b˘=b+N0​﻿)
We plot in figure (b) the plugin approximation, where θ^map\hat{\theta}_{map}θ^map​﻿ is directly injected into the likelihood: p(y∣D,M)=Bin(y∣M,θ^map)p(y|\mathcal{D},M)=\mathrm{Bin}(y|M,\hat{\theta}_{map})p(y∣D,M)=Bin(y∣M,θ^map​)﻿
The long tail of the Bayesian approach makes more less prone to overfitting and Black Swan paradoxes. In both case, the prior is uniform, so this Bayesian property is due to the integration over unknown parameters.
The marginal likelihood for a model M\mathcal{M}M﻿ is defined as:
p(D∣M)=∫p(D∣θ,M)p(θ∣M)dθp(\mathcal{D|M})=\int p(\mathcal{D}|\theta,\mathcal{M})p(\theta|\mathcal{M})d\thetap(D∣M)=∫p(D∣θ,M)p(θ∣M)dθ
Since it is constant in θ\thetaθ﻿ it is not useful for parameter inference, but can help for model or hyperparameters selection (aka Empirical Bayes)
The marginal likelihood for the Beta Binomial is
p(θ∣D)=p(D∣θ)p(θ)p(D)=(NN1)1p(D)1B(a,b)θa+N1−1(1−θ)b+N0−11B(a+N1,b+N0)=(NN1)1p(D)1B(a,b)p(D)=(NN1)B(a+N1,b+N0)B(a,b)\begin{align} p(\theta|\mathcal{D})&=\frac{p(\mathcal{D}|\theta)p(\theta)}{p(\mathcal{D})} \\ &= \binom{N}{N_1}\frac{1}{p(\mathcal{D})}\frac{1}{\Beta(a,b)}\theta^{a+N_1-1}(1-\theta)^{b+N_0-1} \\ \frac{1}{\Beta(a+N_1, b+N_0)}&=\binom{N}{N_1}\frac{1}{p(\mathcal{D})}\frac{1}{\Beta(a,b)} \\ p(\mathcal{D})&= \binom{N}{N_1}\frac{\Beta(a+N_1,b+N_0)}{\Beta(a,b)} \end{align}p(θ∣D)B(a+N1​,b+N0​)1​p(D)​=p(D)p(D∣θ)p(θ)​=(N1​N​)p(D)1​B(a,b)1​θa+N1​−1(1−θ)b+N0​−1=(N1​N​)p(D)1​B(a,b)1​=(N1​N​)B(a,b)B(a+N1​,b+N0​)​​​
Our current prior is rather restrictive. If we want to represent a coin that may be fair but also be equally biased towards head. We can use a Mixture of beta distributions:
p(θ)=0.5 Beta(20,20)+0.5 Beta(30,10)p(\theta)=0.5\,\mathrm{Beta}(20,20)+0.5\,\mathrm{Beta}(30,10)p(θ)=0.5Beta(20,20)+0.5Beta(30,10)
We introduce h=kh=kh=k﻿ meaning that θ\thetaθ﻿ comes from mixture hhh﻿, so the mixture prior is:
p(θ)=∑kp(h=k)p(θ∣h=k)p(\theta)=\sum_k p(h=k)p(\theta|h=k)p(θ)=k∑​p(h=k)p(θ∣h=k)
We can show that the posterior can also be written as a mixture of conjugate distributions:
p(θ∣D)=∑kp(h=k∣D)p(θ∣D,h=k)p(\theta|\mathcal{D})=\sum_k p(h=k|\mathcal{D})p(\theta|\mathcal{D},h=k)p(θ∣D)=k∑​p(h=k∣D)p(θ∣D,h=k)
where the posterior mixing weights are:
p(h=k∣D)=p(D∣h=k)p(h=k)∑k′p(D∣h=k′)p(h=k′)p(h=k|\mathcal{D})=\frac{p(\mathcal{D}|h=k)p(h=k)}{\sum_{k'}p(\mathcal{D}|h=k')p(h=k')}p(h=k∣D)=∑k′​p(D∣h=k′)p(h=k′)p(D∣h=k)p(h=k)​
We can compute this quantity using the equation (40) of the marginal likelihood. If we observe N1=20N_1=20N1​=20﻿ heads and N0=10N_0=10N0​=10﻿ tails, the posterior is:
p(θ∣D)=0.346 Beta(θ∣40,30)+0.654 Beta(θ∣50,20)p(\theta|\mathcal{D})=0.346\,\mathrm{Beta}(\theta|40,30)+0.654\,\mathrm{Beta}(\theta|50,20)p(θ∣D)=0.346Beta(θ∣40,30)+0.654Beta(θ∣50,20)
We can compute the probability that the coin is biased towards head:
Pr⁡(θ>0.5∣D)=∑kPr⁡(θ>0.5∣D,h=k)p(h=k∣D)=0.9604\Pr(\theta>0.5|\mathcal{D})=\sum_k\Pr(\theta>0.5|\mathcal{D},h=k)p(h=k|\mathcal{D})=0.9604Pr(θ>0.5∣D)=k∑​Pr(θ>0.5∣D,h=k)p(h=k∣D)=0.9604
4.6.3 The Dirichlet-multinomial model
We generalize the results from binary variable to categories (e.g. dice). The likelihood is:
p(D∣θ)=∏n=1nCat(yn∣θ)=∏n=1N∏c=1CθcI(yn=c)=∏c=1CθcNcp(\mathcal{D}|\theta)=\prod^n_{n=1}\mathrm{Cat}(y_n|\theta)=\prod^N_{n=1}\prod^C_{c=1}\theta_c^{\mathbb{I}(y_n=c)}=\prod^C_{c=1} \theta_c^{N_c}p(D∣θ)=n=1∏n​Cat(yn​∣θ)=n=1∏N​c=1∏C​θcI(yn​=c)​=c=1∏C​θcNc​​
The conjugate prior is a Dirichlet distribution, which is a multivariate of a beta distribution. It has support over the probability simplex:
SK={θ:0≤θk≤1,∑k=1Kθ=1}S_K=\{\theta:0\leq\theta_k\leq1, \sum^K_{k=1}\theta=1 \}SK​={θ:0≤θk​≤1,k=1∑K​θ=1}
The pdf of Dirichlet:
Dir(θ∣a)=1B(a)∏k=1Kθkak−1I(θ∈SK)\mathrm{Dir}(\theta|\bold{a})=\frac{1}{\Beta(\bold{a})}\prod_{k=1}^K\theta_k^{a_k-1}\mathbb{I}(\theta \in S_K)Dir(θ∣a)=B(a)1​k=1∏K​θkak​−1​I(θ∈SK​)
with the multivariate Beta function:
B(a)=∑k=1KΓ(ak)Γ(∑k=1Kak)\Beta(\bold{a})=\frac{\sum_{k=1}^K\Gamma(a_k)}{\Gamma({\sum_{k=1}^Ka_k})}B(a)=Γ(∑k=1K​ak​)∑k=1K​Γ(ak​)​
The posterior is:
p(θ∣D)∝p(D∣θ)Dir(θ∣a)=∏kθkNk∏kθkak−1=Dir(θ∣a1+N1,...,aK+Nk)=Dir(θ∣a˘)\begin{align} p(\theta|\mathcal{D})&\propto p(\mathcal{D}|\theta)\mathrm{Dir}(\theta|\bold{a}) \\ &= \prod_k \theta_k^{N_k} \prod_k\theta_k^{a_k-1} \\ &= \mathrm{Dir}(\theta|a_1+N_1,...,a_K+N_k)\\ &= \mathrm{Dir}(\theta|\breve{\bold{a}}) \end{align} p(θ∣D)​∝p(D∣θ)Dir(θ∣a)=k∏​θkNk​​k∏​θkak​−1​=Dir(θ∣a1​+N1​,...,aK​+Nk​)=Dir(θ∣a˘)​​
The posterior mean is:
θˉk=a˘k∑k′=1Ka˘k′\bar{\theta}_k=\frac{\breve{a}_k}{\sum^K_{k'=1}\breve{a}_{k'}}θˉk​=∑k′=1K​a˘k′​a˘k​​
The posterior mode (which corresponds to the MAP) is:
θ^k=a˘k−1∑k′=1K(a˘k′−1)\hat{\theta}_k=\frac{\breve{a}_k-1}{\sum_{k'=1}^K(\breve{a}_{k'}-1)}θ^k​=∑k′=1K​(a˘k′​−1)a˘k​−1​
If ak=1a_k=1ak​=1﻿, corresponding to a uniform prior, the MAP becomes the MLE:
θk=NkN\theta_k=\frac{N_k}{N}θk​=NNk​​
The posterior predictive distribution is given by:
p(y=k∣D)=∫p(y=k∣θ)p(θ∣D)dθ=∫θkp(θk∣D)dθk=E[θk∣D]=a˘k∑k′a˘k′\begin{align} p(y=k|\mathcal{D}) &= \int p(y=k|\theta)p(\theta |\mathcal{D})d\theta \\ &= \int \theta_k p(\theta_k|\mathcal{D})d\theta_k = \mathbb{E}[\theta_k|\mathcal{D}]=\frac{\breve{a}_k}{\sum_{k'}\breve{a}_{k'}} \end{align}p(y=k∣D)​=∫p(y=k∣θ)p(θ∣D)dθ=∫θk​p(θk​∣D)dθk​=E[θk​∣D]=∑k′​a˘k′​a˘k​​​​
For a batch of data to predict, it becomes
p(y~∣y)=p(y,y~)p(y)p(\bold{\tilde{y}|y})=\frac{p(\bold{y,\tilde{y}})}{p(\bold{y})}p(y~​∣y)=p(y)p(y,y~​)​
Where the numerator and the denominator are marginal likelihoods, given by:
p(D)=B(a+N)B(a)p(\mathcal{D})=\frac{\Beta(\bold{a}+N)}{\Beta(\bold{a})}p(D)=B(a)B(a+N)​
4.6.4 Gaussian-Gaussian model
We derive the posterior for the parameters for a Gaussian distribution, assuming that the variance is known for simplicity.
We can show that the conjugate prior is also Gaussian. We then apply the Bayes rule for Gaussian, with the observed precision κ\kappaκ﻿ and the prior precision λ\lambdaλ﻿. The posterior is:
p(μ∣D,κ−1)=N(μ∣m˘,λ˘−1)λ˘=λ+Nκm˘=Nκyˉ+λmλ˘=Nκλ+Nκyˉ+λλ+Nκm\begin{align} p(\mu|\mathcal{D},\kappa^{-1}) &= \mathcal{N}(\mu|\breve{m},\breve{\lambda}^{-1}) \\ \breve{\lambda} &= \lambda +N \kappa \\ \breve{m} &= \frac{N \kappa \bar{y}+\lambda m}{\breve{\lambda}}=\frac{N \kappa}{\lambda+N\kappa}\bar{y}+\frac{\lambda}{\lambda+N\kappa}m \end{align}p(μ∣D,κ−1)λ˘m˘​=N(μ∣m˘,λ˘−1)=λ+Nκ=λ˘Nκyˉ​+λm​=λ+NκNκ​yˉ​+λ+Nκλ​m​​
The posterior mean is a convex combination of the empirical mean and the prior mean.
To gain more intuition, after seeing N=1N=1N=1﻿ point, our posterior mean is:
m˘=κλ˘y+λλ˘m=m+κλ˘(y−m)=y−λλ˘(y−m)\begin{align} \breve{m} &=\frac{\kappa}{\breve{\lambda}}y+\frac{\lambda}{\breve{\lambda}}m \\ &= m + \frac{\kappa}{\breve{\lambda}}(y-m) \\ &= y-\frac{\lambda}{\breve{\lambda}}(y-m) \end{align}m˘​=λ˘κ​y+λ˘λ​m=m+λ˘κ​(y−m)=y−λ˘λ​(y−m)​​
The second equation is the prior mean adjusted towards the data y.
The third equation is the data adjusted towards the prior mean, called a shrinkage estimate.
For a Gaussian estimate the posterior mean and posterior mode are the same, thus we can use the above equations to perform MAP estimation.
If we set an uninformative prior λ=0\lambda=0λ=0﻿ and approximate the observed variance σ2\sigma^2σ2﻿ by
s2=1N∑n=1N(yn−yˉ)s^2=\frac{1}{N}\sum_{n=1}^N(y_n-\bar{y})s2=N1​n=1∑N​(yn​−yˉ​)
then the posterior variance of our mean estimate is:
se(μ)=V[μ∣D]=1λ˘=sNse(\mu)=\sqrt{\mathbb{V}[\mu|\mathcal{D}]}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{\breve{\lambda}}}=\frac{s}{\sqrt{N}}se(μ)=V[μ∣D]​=λ˘​1​=N​s​
We see that uncertainty in μ\muμ﻿ reduces at the rate 1/N1/\sqrt{N}1/N​﻿.
Because 95% of the Gaussian distribution is contained within 2 standard deviations of the mean, the 95% credible interval for μ\muμ﻿ is:
I.95(μ∣D)=yˉ±2sNI_{.95}(\mu|\mathcal{D})=\bar{y} ± 2\frac{s}{\sqrt{N}}I.95​(μ∣D)=yˉ​±2N​s​
In the multivariate case, the likelihood becomes:
p(D∣μ)=∏n=1NN(yn∣μ,Σ)=N(2π)D/2∣Σ∣1/2exp⁡(−12∑n=1N(yn−μ)⊤Σ−1(yn−μ))=N(yˉ∣μ,1NΣ)\begin{align} p(\mathcal{D}|\mu)&=\prod_{n=1}^N \mathcal{N}(\bold{y}_n|\mu,\Sigma) \\ &= \frac{N}{(2\pi)^{D/2}|\Sigma|^{1/2}}\exp\big( -\frac{1}{2}\sum_{n=1}^N(\bold{y}_n-\mu)^\top\Sigma^{-1}(\bold{y}_n-\mu) \big) \\ &= \mathcal{N}(\bold{\bar{y}}|\mu,\frac{1}{N}\Sigma) \end{align}p(D∣μ)​=n=1∏N​N(yn​∣μ,Σ)=(2π)D/2∣Σ∣1/2N​exp(−21​n=1∑N​(yn​−μ)⊤Σ−1(yn​−μ))=N(yˉ​∣μ,N1​Σ)​​
Thus we replace the set of observations with their mean and scale down the covariance.
We obtain the same expression for the posterior of the mean than in the univariate case.
4.6.5 Beyond conjugate priors
For most models, there is no prior in the exponential family that conjugates to the likelihood. We briefly discuss various other kinds of prior.
Non informative prior
When we have little to no domain specific knowledge, we prefer “let the data speak for itself” (we get closer to the frequentist statistics).
We can for exemple use a flat prior p(μ)∝1p(\mu) \propto1p(μ)∝1﻿, which can be viewed as an infinitely wide Gaussian.
Hierarchical prior
The parameters of the prior p(θ)p(\theta)p(θ)﻿ are called hyper-parameters ϕ\phiϕ﻿. If there are unknown, we can put a prior on them: this defines a hierarchical Bayesian model.
If we set a non informative prior on ϕ\phiϕ﻿, the joint distribution has the form:
p(ϕ,θ,D)=p(D∣θ)p(θ∣ϕ)p(ϕ)p(\phi,\theta,\mathcal{D})=p(\mathcal{D}|\theta)p(\theta|\phi)p(\phi)p(ϕ,θ,D)=p(D∣θ)p(θ∣ϕ)p(ϕ)
We aim at learning ϕ\phiϕ﻿ by treating the parameters as data points. This is useful when we want to estimate multiple related parameters from different subpopulations.
Empirical prior
The joint distribution of the hierarchical prior can be challenging to compute.
Instead, we make a point wise estimation of the hyper-parameters by maximizing the marginal likelihood:
ϕ^mml(D)=arg max⁡ϕp(D∣ϕ)=arg max⁡ϕ∫p(D∣θ)p(θ∣ϕ)dθ\hat{\phi}_{mml}(\mathcal{D})=\argmax _{\phi}p(\mathcal{D}|\phi)=\argmax_{\phi}\int p(\mathcal{D}|\theta)p(\theta|\phi)d\thetaϕ^​mml​(D)=ϕargmax​p(D∣ϕ)=ϕargmax​∫p(D∣θ)p(θ∣ϕ)dθ
We then compute the conditional posterior p(θ∣ϕ^,D)p(\theta|\hat{\phi},\mathcal{D})p(θ∣ϕ^​,D)﻿ in the usual way.
This violates the principle that the prior should be chosen independently of the data, but we can view it as a computationally cheap approximation of the hierarchical prior.
The more integral one performs, the “more Bayesian” one becomes:
Note that ML-II is less likely to overfit than ML since there are often fewer hyper-parameters ϕ\phiϕ﻿ than parameters θ\thetaθ﻿.
4.6.6 Credible intervals
The posterior distribution is hard to represent in high dimension. We can summarize it via a point estimate (posterior mean or mode) and compute the associated credible interval (which is different from the frequentist confidence interval).
The Credible Interval for 100(1−α)%100(1-\alpha)\%100(1−α)%﻿ is:
Cα(D)=(ℓ,u):P(ℓ≤θ≤u∣D)=1−αC_{\alpha}(\mathcal{D})=(\ell, u):P(\ell \leq \theta \leq u|\mathcal{D})=1-\alphaCα​(D)=(ℓ,u):P(ℓ≤θ≤u∣D)=1−α
If the posterior has a known functional form, we can compute its inverse cdf to find the interval: ℓ=F−1(α/2)\ell=F^{-1}(\alpha/2)ℓ=F−1(α/2)﻿ and u=F−1(1−α/2)u=F^{-1}(1-\alpha/2)u=F−1(1−α/2)﻿.
In general, finding the inverse cdf is hard, so instead we rank samples from the posterior distribution and select our target percentiles.
Sometimes, points that are outside the interval have higher density probability than inner points.
We use the highest posterior density (HPD) to counter this, by finding the threshold p∗p^*p∗﻿:
1−α=∫θ:p(θ∣D)>p∗p(θ∣D)dθ1-\alpha=\int_{\theta:p(\theta|\mathcal{D})> p^*}p(\theta|\mathcal{D})d\theta1−α=∫θ:p(θ∣D)>p∗​p(θ∣D)dθ
and then defines the HPD as:
Cα(D)=θ:p(θ∣D)≥p∗C_{\alpha}(\mathcal{D})=\theta:p(\theta|\mathcal{D})\geq p^*Cα​(D)=θ:p(θ∣D)≥p∗
4.6.7 Bayesian machine learning
So far, we have focused on unconditional models of the form p(y∣θ)p(y|\theta)p(y∣θ)﻿.
In supervised machine learning, we focus on conditional models of the form p(y∣x,θ)p(y|x,\theta)p(y∣x,θ)﻿.
Our posterior becomes p(θ∣D)p(\theta|\mathcal{D})p(θ∣D)﻿ with D={(xn,yn):n=1:N}\mathcal{D}=\{(x_n,y_n):n=1:N\}D={(xn​,yn​):n=1:N}﻿
Once we have computed the posterior over the θ\thetaθ﻿, we can compute the posterior predictive distribution over yyy﻿ given xxx﻿:
p(y∣x,D)=∫p(y∣x,θ)p(θ∣D)dθp(y|x,\mathcal{D})=\int p(y|x,\theta)p(\theta|\mathcal{D})d\theta p(y∣x,D)=∫p(y∣x,θ)p(θ∣D)dθ
Computing this integral is often intractable. Instead, we approximate that there is a single best model θ^\hat{\theta}θ^﻿, such as the MLE.
p(θ∣D)=δ(θ−θ^)p(\theta|\mathcal{D})=\delta(\theta-\hat{\theta})p(θ∣D)=δ(θ−θ^)
Using the plugin approximation, the predictive distribution is now:
p(y∣x,D)≈∫p(y∣x,θ)δ(θ−θ^)dθ=p(y∣x,θ^)p(y|x,\mathcal{D})\approx\int p(y|x,\theta)\delta(\theta-\hat{\theta})d\theta=p(y|x,\hat{\theta})p(y∣x,D)≈∫p(y∣x,θ)δ(θ−θ^)dθ=p(y∣x,θ^)
This is the standard machine learning approach of fitting a model θ^\hat{\theta}θ^﻿ then making prediction.
However, as this approximation can overfit, we average over a few plausible parameters values (instead of the fully Bayesian approach above). Here are 2 examples:
Scalar input, binary output
To perform binary classification, we can use a logistic regression of the form:
p(y∣x,θ)=Ber(y∣σ(w⊤x+b))p(y|x,\theta)=\mathrm{Ber}(y|\sigma(w^\top x+b))p(y∣x,θ)=Ber(y∣σ(w⊤x+b))
In other words:
p(y=1∣x,θ)=σ(w⊤x+b)=11+e−w⊤x+bp(y=1|x,\theta)=\sigma(w^\top x+b)=\frac{1}{1+e^{-w^\top x + b}}p(y=1∣x,θ)=σ(w⊤x+b)=1+e−w⊤x+b1​
We find the MLE θ^\hat{\theta}θ^﻿ for this 1d logistic regression and use the plugin approximation to get the posterior predictive p(y=1∣x,θ^)p(y=1|x,\hat{\theta})p(y=1∣x,θ^)﻿
The decision boundary is defined as:
σ(w⊤x∗+b)=1/2⇒x∗=−bw\sigma(w^\top x^* + b)=1/2 \Rightarrow x^*=-\frac{b}{w}σ(w⊤x∗+b)=1/2⇒x∗=−wb​
We capture the uncertainty by approximating the posterior p(θ∣D)p(\theta|\mathcal{D})p(θ∣D)﻿.
Given this, we can approximate the mean and the 95% credible interval of the posterior predictive distribution using a Monte Carlo approximation:
p(y=1∣x,D)≈1S∑s=1Sp(y=1∣x,θs)Cα(x,D)={θs:p(θs∣x,D)>p∗}\begin{align}p(y=1|x,\mathcal{D})&\approx \frac{1}{S}\sum_{s=1}^Sp(y=1|x,\theta_s) \\ C_{\alpha}(x,\mathcal{D}) &= \{\theta_s:p(\theta_s|x,\mathcal{D})> p^*\} \end{align}p(y=1∣x,D)Cα​(x,D)​≈S1​s=1∑S​p(y=1∣x,θs​)={θs​:p(θs​∣x,D)>p∗}​​
where θs∼p(θ∣D)\theta_s \sim p(\theta|\mathcal{D})θs​∼p(θ∣D)﻿ is a posterior sample.
We can also compute a distribution over the decision boundary:
p(x∗∣D)=1S∑s=1Sδ(x∗−(−bsws))p(x^*|\mathcal{D})=\frac{1}{S}\sum_{s=1}^S \delta(x^*-(-\frac{b_s}{w_s}))p(x∗∣D)=S1​s=1∑S​δ(x∗−(−ws​bs​​))
where (bs,ws)=θs(b_s,w_s)=\theta_s(bs​,ws​)=θs​﻿
Binary input, scalar output
We now predict the delivery time yyy﻿ for a package from company A (x=0x=0x=0﻿) or company B (x=1x=1x=1﻿).
Our model is:
p(y∣x,θ)=N(y∣μx,σx2)p(y|x,\theta)=\mathcal{N}(y|\mu_x,\sigma^2_x)p(y∣x,θ)=N(y∣μx​,σx2​)
The parameters are θ=(μ0,μ1,σ0,σ1)\theta=(\mu_0, \mu_1, \sigma_0, \sigma_1)θ=(μ0​,μ1​,σ0​,σ1​)﻿ so we can fit this model using MLE.
However, the issue with the plug-in approximation p(y∣x,θ^)p(y|x,\hat{\theta})p(y∣x,θ^)﻿ is that in the case of one single point of observation, we don’t capture uncertainty, our MLE for standard deviations are σ^0=σ^1=0\hat{\sigma}_0=\hat{\sigma}_1=0σ^0​=σ^1​=0﻿.
Instead, the Bayesian approach using the Bayes rule for Gaussian allows to compute the posterior variance and the credible interval.
4.6.8 Computational issues
Usually, performing the Bayesian update is intractable except for simple cases like conjugate models or latent variables with few possible values.
We perform approximate posterior inference for a Beta-Bernoulli model:
p(θ∣D)∝[∏n=1NBin(yn∣θ)]Beta(θ∣a,b)p(\theta|\mathcal{D})\propto \Bigg[\prod_{n=1}^N \mathrm{Bin}(y_n|\theta)\Bigg] \mathrm{Beta}(\theta | a, b)p(θ∣D)∝[n=1∏N​Bin(yn​∣θ)]Beta(θ∣a,b)
with D\mathcal{D}D﻿ consisting in 10 heads and 1 tails, with a uniform prior.
Grid approximation
The simplest approach is to partition θ\thetaθ﻿ in a finite set θ1,...,θK\theta_1,...,\theta_Kθ1​,...,θK​﻿ and approximate the posterior by brute-force enumeration:
p(θ=θk∣D)=p(D∣θk)p(θk)∑k′=1Kp(D∣θk′)p(θk′)p(\theta=\theta_k|\mathcal{D})=\frac{p(\mathcal{D} | \theta_k)p(\theta_k)}{\sum_{k'=1}^K p(\mathcal{D}|\theta_{k'})p(\theta_{k'})}p(θ=θk​∣D)=∑k′=1K​p(D∣θk′​)p(θk′​)p(D∣θk​)p(θk​)​
This captures the skewness of our posterior, but the number of grid points scales exponentially in high dimension.
Laplace approximation
We approximate the posterior using a multivariate Gaussian as follow:
p(θ∣D)≈1Zq(θ)p(\theta|\mathcal{D}) \approx \frac{1}{Z}q(\theta)p(θ∣D)≈Z1​q(θ)
where Z=p(D)Z=p(\mathcal{D})Z=p(D)﻿ and q(θ)=N(θ∣μ,Σ)q(\theta)=\mathcal{N}(\theta|\mu,\Sigma)q(θ)=N(θ∣μ,Σ)﻿
We can show that:
q(θ)=N(θ∣μ=θ^map,Σ=H)Z=p(θ^map,D)(2π)D/2∣H∣−1/2\begin{align} q(\theta)&=\mathcal{N}(\theta|\mu=\hat{\theta}_{map},\Sigma=H) \\ Z &= p(\hat{\theta}_{map},\mathcal{D}) (2\pi)^{D/2}|H|^{-1/2} \end{align}q(θ)Z​=N(θ∣μ=θ^map​,Σ=H)=p(θ^map​,D)(2π)D/2∣H∣−1/2​​
This is easy to apply, since after computing the MAP estimate, we just need to compute the Hessian at the mode (in high dimensional space, we use a diagonal approximation).
However we see that the Laplace approximation fits poorly when the posterior is skewed (whereas Gaussian is symmetric).
We can improve the fit by replacing the variable: α=logit θ\alpha=\mathrm{logit}\, \thetaα=logitθ﻿
Variational inference (VI)
VI is another optimization base posterior approximation. It aims at minimizing some discrepancy DDD﻿ between our posterior distribution ppp﻿ and a distribution qqq﻿ from some tractable family (like MVN):
q∗=arg min⁡q∈QD(q,p)q^*=\argmin_{q \in \mathcal{Q}} D(q,p)q∗=q∈Qargmin​D(q,p)
If DDD﻿ is the KL divergence, we can derivate the evidence lower bound (ELBO) of the marginal likelihood. Maximizing the ELBO improves the posterior approximation.
Markov Chain Monte Carlo (MCMC)
Although VI is fast, it can give a biased approximation since it is restricted to a specific function form q∈Qq\in\mathcal{Q}q∈Q﻿.
Monte Carlo is a more flexible, non-parametric approach:
q(θ)=1S∑s=1Sδ(θ−θs)q(\theta)=\frac{1}{S}\sum^S_{s=1}\delta(\theta-\theta_s)q(θ)=S1​s=1∑S​δ(θ−θs​)
The key issue is to create posterior samples θs∼p(θ∣D)\theta_s \sim p(\theta|\mathcal{D})θs​∼p(θ∣D)﻿ without having to evaluate the normalization constant p(D)=∫p(θ,D)dθp(\mathcal{D})=\int p(\theta,\mathcal{D})d\thetap(D)=∫p(θ,D)dθ﻿
MCMC —and Hamiltonian Monte Carlo (HMC)— speeds up this method by augmenting this algorithm with gradient based information derived from ∇log⁡p(θ,D)\nabla \log p(\theta,\mathcal{D})∇logp(θ,D)﻿.
4.7 Frequentist statistics
4.7.1 Sampling distribution
In frequentist statistics, uncertainty is represented by the sampling distribution on an estimator.
An estimator is a decision procedure mapping observed data to an action (here the action is a parameter vector).
We denote it by θ^=π(D)\hat{\theta}=\pi(\mathcal{D})θ^=π(D)﻿, where θ^\hat{\theta}θ^﻿ can be the MLE, MAP estimate or MOM estimate.
The sampling distribution is the distribution of results if we applied the estimator multiple times to different datasets from some distribution
We sample SSS﻿ different datasets of size NNN﻿ from some true model p(x∣θ∗)p(x|\theta^*)p(x∣θ∗)﻿:
D~(s)={xn∼p(xn∣θ∗):n=1:N}\tilde{\mathcal{D}}^{(s)}=\{x_n \sim p(x_n|\theta^*):n=1:N\}D~(s)={xn​∼p(xn​∣θ∗):n=1:N}
For brevity, we denote it D(s)∼θ∗\mathcal{D}^{(s)} \sim \theta^*D(s)∼θ∗﻿
If we apply the estimator to each D(s)\mathcal{D}^{(s)}D(s)﻿:
p(π(D~)=θ∣D~∼θ∗)≈1S∑s=1Sδ(θ=π(D(s)))p(\pi(\mathcal{\tilde{D}})=\theta|\mathcal{\tilde{D}}\sim \theta^*) \approx \frac{1}{S} \sum^S_{s=1} \delta (\theta=\pi(\mathcal{D}^{(s)}))p(π(D~)=θ∣D~∼θ∗)≈S1​s=1∑S​δ(θ=π(D(s)))
We typically need to approximate it with Monte Carlo.
4.7.2 Gaussian approximation of the sampling distribution of the MLE
The most common estimator is the MLE.
When the sample size becomes large, the sampling distribution of the MLE becomes Gaussian:
p(π(D^)=θ^∣D^∼θ∗)→N(θ^∣θ∗,(NF(θ∗))−1)p(\pi(\mathcal{\hat{D}})=\hat{\theta}|\mathcal{\hat{D}}\sim \theta^*)\rightarrow\mathcal{N}(\hat{\theta}|\theta^*, (N\mathrm{F}(\theta^*))^{-1})p(π(D^)=θ^∣D^∼θ∗)→N(θ^∣θ∗,(NF(θ∗))−1)
F\mathrm{F}F﻿ is the Fisher information matrix (FIM). It measures the amount of curvature of the log-likelihood at its peak.
Fij=Ex∼θ[(∂∂θilog⁡p(x∣θ))(∂∂θjlog⁡p(x∣θ))⊤]\mathrm{F}_{ij}=\mathbb{E}_{x\sim\theta}\Big[\Big(\frac{\partial}{\partial \theta_i} \log p(x|\theta)\Big)(\frac{\partial}{\partial \theta_j}\log p(x|\theta)\Big)^\top\Big]Fij​=Ex∼θ​[(∂θi​∂​logp(x∣θ))(∂θj​∂​logp(x∣θ))⊤]
One can show that the FIM is also the Hessian of the NLL:
Fij=−Ex∼θ[∂2∂θiθjlog⁡p(x∣θ)]\mathrm{F}_{ij}=-\mathbb{E}_{x\sim\theta}\Big[\frac{\partial^2}{\partial \theta_i \theta_j}\log p(x|\theta)\Big]Fij​=−Ex∼θ​[∂θi​θj​∂2​logp(x∣θ)]
A log-likelihood function with high curvature (a large Hessian) will result in a low variance estimate since the parameters are well determined by the data.
4.7.3 Bootstrap approximation of the sampling distribution of any estimator
When the estimator is a complex function of the data (not jus the MLE) or when the sample size is small, we can approximate the sampling distribution using a Monte Carlo technique called the bootstrap.
The parametric bootstrap
Compute θ^=π(D)\hat{\theta}= \pi(\mathcal{D})θ^=π(D)﻿
Use it as plugin to create SSS﻿ datasets of size NNN﻿:
D~(s)={xn∼p(xn∣θ^):i=1:N}\tilde{\mathcal{D}}^{(s)}=\{x_n\sim p(x_n|\hat{\theta}):i=1:N\}D~(s)={xn​∼p(xn​∣θ^):i=1:N}﻿
Compute our estimator for each sample, θ^s=π(D^(s))\hat{\theta}^{s}=\pi(\hat{\mathcal{D}}^{(s)})θ^s=π(D^(s))﻿. This empirical distribution is our estimate of the sampling distribution
The non-parametric bootstrap
Sample NNN﻿ points from D\mathcal{D}D﻿ with replacement, this create D(s)\mathcal{D}^{(s)}D(s)﻿
Compute our estimator as for each sample and draw the empirical distribution.
Note that on average, a sample only has 63.2% of unique data point, since the probability that an item is picked at least once is (1−(1−1/N)N)(1-(1-1/N)^N)(1−(1−1/N)N)﻿, which converges to 1−e−1=0.6321-e^{-1}=0.6321−e−1=0.632﻿
The bootstrap is a “poor man’s” posterior. In the common case where the estimator is a MLE and the prior is uniform, they are similar.
4.7.4 Confidence intervals
We use the variability induced by the sampling distribution to estimate the uncertainty of an a parameter estimate. We define a 100(1−α)%100(1-\alpha)\%100(1−α)%﻿-confidence interval as:
Pr⁡(θ∈I(D~)∣D~∼θ)=1−α\Pr(\theta\in I(\mathcal{\tilde{D}})|\mathcal{\tilde{D}}\sim \theta)=1-\alphaPr(θ∈I(D~)∣D~∼θ)=1−α
where the hypothetical data D~\tilde{\mathcal{D}}D~﻿ is used to derives the interval I(D~)=(ℓ(D~),u(D~))I(\mathcal{\tilde{D}})=(\ell(\mathcal{\tilde{D}}), u(\mathcal{\tilde{D}}))I(D~)=(ℓ(D~),u(D~))﻿.
If α=0.05\alpha=0.05α=0.05﻿, this means that if we repeatedly sample data and compute I(D~)I(\mathcal{\tilde{D}})I(D~)﻿, 95% of such intervals would contains the parameter θ.\theta.θ.﻿
Suppose θ∗\theta^* θ∗﻿ is the unknown true parameter but we know Δ=θ^−θ∗\Delta=\hat{\theta}-\theta^*Δ=θ^−θ∗﻿:
Pr⁡(δα/2≤θ^−θ∗≤δ1−α/2)=1−α\Pr(\delta_{\alpha/2} \leq \hat{\theta}-\theta^*\leq \delta_{1-\alpha/2})=1-\alphaPr(δα/2​≤θ^−θ∗≤δ1−α/2​)=1−α
By rearranging, we find (θ^−δ1−α/2,θ^−δα/2)(\hat{\theta}-\delta_{1-\alpha/2}, \hat{\theta}-\delta_{\alpha/2})(θ^−δ1−α/2​,θ^−δα/2​)﻿ is a 100(1−α)%100(1-\alpha)\% 100(1−α)%﻿ CI.
In most cases, we assume a Gaussian approximation to the sampling distribution:
NF(θ^)(θ^−θ∗)∼N(0,1)\sqrt{N \mathrm{F}(\hat{\theta})}(\hat{\theta}-\theta^*) \sim N(0, 1)NF(θ^)​(θ^−θ∗)∼N(0,1)
and thus we can compute and approximate CI using:
θ^±zα/2se^\hat{\theta} ± z_{\alpha/2}\hat{se}θ^±zα/2​se^
where zα/2z_{\alpha/2}zα/2​﻿ is the α/2\alpha/2α/2﻿ quantile of the Gaussian CDF and se^=1/NF(θ^)\hat{se}=\sqrt{1/N\mathrm{F}(\hat{\theta}})se^=1/NF(θ^​)﻿ is the estimate standard error.
If the Gaussian approximation is not satisfactory, we can bootstrap the empirical distribution θ^(D)−θ^(D(s))\hat{\theta}(\mathcal{D})-\hat{\theta}(\mathcal{D}^{(s)})θ^(D)−θ^(D(s))﻿ as an approximation to Δ\DeltaΔ﻿.
4.7.5 Confidence intervals are not credible
A frequentist 95% CI is defined as an interval such that Pr⁡(θ∈I(D~)∣D~∼θ)=0.95\Pr(\theta \in I(\mathcal{\tilde{D}})|\mathcal{\tilde{D}}\sim\theta)=0.95Pr(θ∈I(D~)∣D~∼θ)=0.95﻿.
If I repeat the experiment over and over, then 95% of the time the CI contains the true mean.
It doesn’t mean that the parameter is 95% likely to live in the interval given by the observed data.
That quantity is instead given by the credible interval p(θ∈I∣D)p(\theta \in I|\mathcal{D})p(θ∈I∣D)﻿
These concepts are different: in the frequentist view, θ\thetaθ﻿ is treated as a unknown, fixed constant, and the data as random. In the Bayesian view, the data is fixed (as it is known) and θ\thetaθ﻿ is random.
4.7.6 The bias-variance tradeoff
In frequentist, data is a random variable drawn from some true but unknown distribution p∗(D)p^*(\mathcal{D})p∗(D)﻿. So the estimator has a sampling distribution p∗(θ^(D))p^*(\hat{\theta}(\mathcal{D}))p∗(θ^(D))﻿
The bias is defined as:
bias(θ^(.))≜E[θ^(D)]−θ∗\mathrm{bias}(\hat{\theta}(.))\triangleq\mathbb{E}[\hat{\theta}(\mathcal{D})]-\theta^*bias(θ^(.))≜E[θ^(D)]−θ∗
The MLE of the Gaussian mean is unbiased E[xˉ]=μ\mathbb{E}[\bar{x}]=\muE[xˉ]=μ﻿, but if μ\muμ﻿ is not known, the MLE of the Gaussian variance is biased:
E[σmle2]=E[1N∑i=1N(xi−xˉ)2]=N−1Nσ2\mathbb{E}[\sigma_{mle}^2]=\mathbb{E}[\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^N(x_i-\bar{x})^2]=\frac{N-1}{N}\sigma^2E[σmle2​]=E[N1​i=1∑N​(xi​−xˉ)2]=NN−1​σ2
Intuitively, this is because we use up one point to get the mean. The unbiased estimator for the Gaussian variance is:
σunb2=1N−1∑i=1N(xi−xˉ)2=NN−1σmle2\sigma^2_{unb}=\frac{1}{N-1}\sum_{i=1}^N(x_i-\bar{x})^2=\frac{N}{N-1}\sigma^2_{mle}σunb2​=N−11​i=1∑N​(xi​−xˉ)2=N−1N​σmle2​
The bias variance tradeoff is given by:
MSE=E[(θ^−θ∗)2]=E[[(θ^−θˉ)−(θ∗−θˉ)]2]=E[(θ^−θˉ)2]−2E[θ^−θˉ](θˉ−θ∗)+(θ∗−θˉ)2=V[θ^]+bias2(θ^)\begin{align} MSE&=\mathbb{E}[(\hat{\theta}-\theta^*)^2]\\&=\mathbb{E}[[(\hat{\theta}-\bar{\theta})-(\theta^*-\bar{\theta})]^2]\\ &= \mathbb{E}[(\hat{\theta}-\bar{\theta})^2]-2\mathbb{E}[\hat{\theta} - \bar{\theta}](\bar{\theta} - \theta^*)+(\theta^*-\bar{\theta})^2 \\ &= \mathbb{V}[\hat{\theta}]+\mathrm{bias}^2(\hat{\theta}) \end{align}MSE​=E[(θ^−θ∗)2]=E[[(θ^−θˉ)−(θ∗−θˉ)]2]=E[(θ^−θˉ)2]−2E[θ^−θˉ](θˉ−θ∗)+(θ∗−θˉ)2=V[θ^]+bias2(θ^)​​
It can be wise to use a biased estimator as long as it reduces the variance by more than the square of the bias.
MAP estimator for a Gaussian mean
Suppose we want to estimate the mean of a Gaussian from x=(x1,...,xn)x=(x_1,...,x_n)x=(x1​,...,xn​)﻿.
The MLE is unbiased and has a variance of V[xˉ∣θ∗]=σ2/N\mathbb{V}[\bar{x}|\theta^*]=\sigma^2/NV[xˉ∣θ∗]=σ2/N﻿
The MAP under a prior of the form N(θ0,σ2/κ0)\mathcal{N}(\theta_0,\sigma^2/\kappa_0)N(θ0​,σ2/κ0​)﻿ is:
x~≜NN+κ0xˉ+κ0N+κ0θ0=wxˉ+(1−w)θ0\tilde{x}\triangleq \frac{N}{N+\kappa_0}\bar{x}+\frac{\kappa_0}{N+\kappa_0}\theta_0=w\bar{x}+(1-w)\theta_0x~≜N+κ0​N​xˉ+N+κ0​κ0​​θ0​=wxˉ+(1−w)θ0​
The bias and variance are given by:
V[x~∣θ∗]=w2σ2/Nbias=E[x~]−θ∗=wθ∗+(1−w)θ0−θ∗=(w−1)(θ∗−θ0)\begin{align} \mathbb{V}[\tilde{x}|\theta^*]&=w^2\sigma^2/N \\ \mathrm{bias} &= \mathbb{E}[\tilde{x}]-\theta^*\\&=w\theta^*+(1-w)\theta_0-\theta^*\\&=(w-1)(\theta^* - \theta_0) \end{align}V[x~∣θ∗]bias​=w2σ2/N=E[x~]−θ∗=wθ∗+(1−w)θ0​−θ∗=(w−1)(θ∗−θ0​)​​
MAP estimator for linear regression
MAP estimator for classification
If we use a 0-1 loss instead of the MSE, the frequentist risk is now Var×biasVar \times biasVar×bias﻿. If the estimate is on the correct side of the classification, then the bias is negative, and decreasing the variance will decrease the misclassification rate.
However, if the estimate is wrong, the bias is positive and it pays to increase the variance. This illustrates that it is better to focus on the expected loss in classification, not on the bias and variance.
